data.title: The Churchill Day Book for 1943: Turning of the “Hinge of Fate”
data.meta_description: We may rate 1943 as the last swing of the “Hinge of Fate,” a year marked by fateful conferences amidst the march to victory.
data.text:
The Churchill Day Book

The Day Book is an old project, first proposed by Dalton Newfield, the accomplished editor of Finest Hour from 1970 to 1975. After his death in 1982, the work was periodically revived but proved formidable. In the digital age, The Churchill Project now revives the effort. We invite any reader intrigued by logging all of Churchill’s days to supply more years. Please contact [email protected].

Dalton Newfield’s objective was a single reference pinpointing Churchill’s location and activity for every day of his life. He was undaunted by the fact that it would cover 33,000 days. Given the scope, detail is avoided. That is provided by the Official Biography and legions of other biographies and specialized studies. Knowing where Churchill was, with the briefest description of his activities, is invaluable to researchers, students, scholars, or just the curious.

“Action This Day”: 1943

The year 1943 was the final turning point of the Second World War. It was the year of the Axis surrenders at Stalingrad and Tunisia, the Allied invasion of Italy. Mussolini fell, strategic bombing intensified. Germany lost the Battle of Kursk and the Battle of the Atlantic. Overall, 1943 proved what had been apparent since the Soviets and Americans entered the war: Bitter fighting lay ahead, but Germany was sure to lose.

Winston Churchill’s 1943 schedule was one of relentless activity. He worked abed in mornings and continued through the day. A late afternoon nap allowed extended his day into the early morning hours. Assisted by his personal staff, he worked with his closest political and military officials. He read cables, correspondence, communiqués, newspapers, government reports, intelligence data, and other documents at a voracious rate. His foreign secretary, Anthony Eden, compared the reading regime to reading a novel a day.

Each day Churchill chaired meetings of numerous committees, the most important being the War Cabinet. These meetings often descended into arguments and contentious exchanges. The Prime Minister did not hesitate to “pester, nag, and bite.” Grave subjects from military strategy to postwar Europe were decided. Churchill issued “Action This Day” memos by the dozens to officials; wrote his own speeches; and drafted and approved cables to other world leaders, most importantly Stalin and Roosevelt. In 1943 he sent about 300 cables to Roosevelt and at least twenty-five to Stalin.

Foreign affairs

Churchill met with monarchs, presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers, visiting envoys and delegations. He brought into discussions generals, admirals, air marshals, ambassadors, high commissioners, and Members of Parliament. When both were in the country, they held a weekly luncheon at Buckingham Palace. As prime minister in a parliamentary system, WSC appeared in the House of Commons to speak and answer questions from the members. He inspected military units, and addressed civilians from Cyprus to Quebec.

In 1943 Churchill travelled thousands of miles by plane, train, car and ship. He spent 147 days outside of Britain, visiting twelve countries. He participated in the conferences at Casablanca, Washington, Quebec, Cairo, and Teheran. During the year he delivered set-piece speeches to the House of Commons, addressed a joint session of the United States Congress, and made worldwide radio broadcasts. He chaired ninety meetings of the War Cabinet.

Health concerns

Churchill’s grueling 1943 schedule was broken two major periods of pneumonia. He was bedridden in February-March and late in the year. Lord Moran, his personal physician, worried that the PM was going to die. But the last days of 1943 saw him recuperating from his latest illness in Marrakesh, Morocco.

As diversions, Churchill regularly watched movies, occasionally went to the theatre and played bezique. He sought refuge at Chequers on weekends, and occasionally escaped to Chartwell. He did less reading for relaxation during the war. There was no oil painting, save for one opportunity early in 1943 at Marrakesh. He was supported through the strain of war by his wife, daughters, and brother; less so by his son Randolph.

January

1: London; departs for Chequers, the country home of prime ministers.

2: Chequers.

3: Chequers; guests included General Frederick Browning of Airborne Forces.

4: Chequers; returns to London; chairs War Cabinet.

5-8: London; chairs several War Cabinets.

10: Meets with Georges Catroux, General Delegate of Free France in the Levant.

11: London; War Cabinet.

12: London; audience with King George VI; War Cabinet; flies for Casablanca.

13: Casablanca.

14: Discusses 1943 plans with President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

15-24: Casablanca Conference.

24: Casablanca with FDR, de Gaulle, Giraud; drives with FDR to Marrakesh.

25: Marrakesh; sees FDR off for Washington; paints “Katoubia Mosque”; flies to Cairo.

26: Cairo Aerodrome and British Embassy.

27-30: Cairo; military conferences.

30: Flies to Adana, Turkey; meets President Inönü and Prime Minister Saracoglu.

31: Adana with Turkish leaders; flies to Cyprus.

February

1: Nicosia, Cyprus; inspects Fourth Hussars; addresses Cypriot leaders; flies to Cairo.

2: Cairo; Germany surrenders at Stalingrad.

3: Flies to Tripoli; drives amid cheering throngs to GHQ, addresses 8th Army soldiers.

4: Tripoli; 8th Army review; addresses New Zealand Division; departs for Algeria.

5: Maison Blanche, Algiers; meets with Eisenhower; flight to England delayed.

6: Algiers with Eisenhower, French officials, military commanders; flies to England.

7: Arrives UK, travels by train to Paddington Station; War Cabinet.

8: London.

9: London; audience with the King; greeted by cheers in House of Commons.

10: London; War Cabinet; speaks in the House.

11: London, Commons speech on war situation and January travels.

12-14: London; unwell and in bed.

15: London; chairs War Cabinet despite heavy cold; lunches with Lord Baldwin.

16: London, ill; his doctor Lord Moran diagnoses pneumonia.

17: London; chairs War Cabinet despite illness.

18-21: Ill and in bed; condition improving on 21st.

22: London; ill and in bed; dictates reply to the King’s handwritten letter of concern.

23-28: London, still bedridden; watches film Desert Victory on the 24th.

March

1-2: London; bulletin released reporting condition improving daily.

3: London; recovering; War Cabinet; departs for Chequers.

4-6: Chequers; recuperating; continues to work on dispatch boxes and telephone calls.

7: Chequers; recuperating; drives to Ditchley Park for luncheon.

8: Chequers; recuperating; luncheon with King George VI.

9-14: Chequers; recuperating, King George of Greece visits on 12th.

15: Departs Chequers for London; War Cabinet.

16: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; Defence Committee; cheered in Commons.

17: London; speaks in the House of Commons; chairs Anti-U-boat Committee.

18: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

19: London; War Cabinet; departs for Chequers.

20-21: Chequers; radio broadcast on postwar planning on 21st.

22: Returns London; War Cabinet.

23: London; House of Commons; audience with King George VI.

24: London; speaks in the House on the successful 1943 Tunisian campaign.

25: London; War Cabinet; speaks in the House.

26: Interviewed by Manchester Guardian; visits U.S. 8th Air Force HQ; Chequers.

27-28: Chequers.

29: London; War Cabinet; interviewed by The Times.

30: London; House of Commons.

31: London; statement in a secret session of the House of Commons.

April

1: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

2: London; meets with de Gaulle; departs for Chequers.

3-4: Chequers.

5: Returns to London, War Cabinet; meets with U.S. Ambassador John Winant.

6: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; Cabinet meetings; House of Commons.

7: London; speaks in the Commons; chairs Cabinet meeting.

8: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

9: London; War Cabinet.

10-12: London: War Cabinet; House of Commons.

13: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; speaks in the Commons.

14: London; War Cabinet.

15: London; War Cabinet; speaks in Commons; meets with Władysław Sikorski, saying about the Katyn massacre: “the Bolsheviks can be very cruel.”

16: London; meets with Clement Attlee and Leo Amery; departs for Chequers.

17-18: Chequers.

19: Returns London via Hatfield to inspect aircraft; War Cabinet.

20: London: Royal audience; speaks in Commons; meets with Conservative ministers.

21-23: London; House of Commons, chairs daily War Cabinets.

24-26: Chartwell for a rare wartime visit, returns to London on 26th.

27-29: London; two meetings with Sikorski; daily War Cabinets.

30: London; de Gaulle; with Clementine, visits daughter Mary’s Hyde Park gun battery.

May

1-3: London; War Cabinet on 3rd.

4: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; House of Commons; entrains for the Clyde.

5: Arrives Greenock; transfers to the Queen Mary; sails for United States.

6-10: At sea aboard Queen Mary; meetings with Chiefs of Staff and other officials.

11-25: Washington Conference with President Roosevelt.

11: Queen Mary anchors off Staten Island; train to Washington; arrives at White House.

12: White House; meets with FDR and Combined Chiefs of Staff.

13: White House; meets with FDR and Czech President Edvard Beneš.

14: Washington; broadcasts on Home Guard and Washington Conference; drives to Shangri La (now Camp David), Maryland for weekend.

15-16: Shangri La, Maryland with President Roosevelt.

17: Returns to Washington, meets with Bernard Baruch; moves to British Embassy.

18: Washington; accompanies Duke and Duchess of Windsor to FDR meeting; meets with Canadian Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

19: Washington; second speech to U.S. Congress; meets with Senate and House Foreign Affairs Committees, Combined Chiefs, FDR and Mackenzie King.

20: Washington; Pacific War Council with FDR, King and Philippine President Quezon.

21: Washington; Mackenzie King, FDR. Combined Chiefs of Staff.

22: Washington with Vice-President Henry Wallace, War Secretary Stimson, and a delegation of Senators and Representatives.

23: Washington; moves back to White House; meets with FDR.

24: White House; meets with FDR, Wallace. Combined Chiefs of Staff.

25: White House; meets with Combined Chiefs; press conference with FDR.

26: Flies with General Marshall to Newfoundland, then on to Gibraltar.

27: Gibraltar after 17-hour flight; U.S. announces full agreement on 1943 war plans.

28: Tours Gibraltar with Marshall; they then fly to Algiers to meet Eisenhower.

28: Admiral Cunningham’s villa, Algiers; inspects submarines. After “a very delightful speech” WSC in tears speaks of “boys walking in the valley of the shadow of death.”

29: Algiers; confers with Eisenhower, Alexander, French General Alphonse Joseph Georges.

30-31: Algiers; military conferences with Eisenhower.

June

1: Algiers; observes USAAF Pantelleria bombing briefing; flies to Tunis, drives to Carthage; addresses 3000 troops in the Roman amphitheater.

2: Tunis; tours local battlefields; speaks to soldiers; flies to Algiers, sometimes taking controls.

3: Algiers; military conference with Eisenhower.

4: Algiers; meets with de Gaulle and Giraud; flies to Gibraltar and England.

5: Lands at Northolt; War Cabinet; drives to Chequers.

6-7: Chequers; returns London; War Cabinet on 7th.

8: London; Royal audience; Commons speech: “Brilliant prospects lie before us.”

9: London; War Cabinet; attends premiere of The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp.

10-12: London; War Cabinet on 10th.

13: Chequers.

14: Drives to Chartwell for the day; returns to London to meet Wavell.

15-16: London; daily War Cabinets.

17: London; drives to Chequers.

18-20: Chequers.

21: London; War Cabinet.

22-23: London; luncheon with Queen Elizabeth on 22nd.

24: London; War Cabinet; speaks in the House of Commons.

25: London and Northolt; breakfasts with King George; drives to Buckingham Palace, Chequers.

26: Chequers; guests include General Edward Spears.

27: Chequers; watching bombing film, he asks “Are we beasts? Are we taking this too far?”

28: Chequers; drives to London; War Cabinet.

29: London; audience with King; War Cabinet.

30: London; receives Freedom of London at Guildhall; predicts heavy fighting in 1943.

July

1: London; War Cabinet; speaks in the House of Commons

2: London; War Cabinet; departs for Chequers

3-4: Chequers; guests include Noël Coward.

5: London; War Cabinet.

6: London; audience with the King; delivers tribute to Sikorksi in the House of Commons.

7: London; War Cabinet; dines with the King at 10 Downing Street.

8: London; War Cabinet; meets Polish PM Stanislaw Mikolajczyk.

9: London; War Cabinet; departs for Chequers.

10-11: Chequers. Allies invade Sicily.

12: London; War Cabinet.

13: London; audience with the King; War Cabinet.

14: London; War Cabinet; broadcast to Polish Forces; meets War Secretary Stimson.

15: London; Sikorski funeral, Westminster Cathedral; meets with Vannevar Bush.

16-17: London; War Cabinet on 16th.

18-19: Chequers; inspects southeast military units; returns London; War Cabinet.

20: London; audience with King George VI; speaks in Commons.

21: London; Commons; meets again with Prime Minister Mikolajczyk.

22: London; War Cabinet; National Liberal Club and Commons; holds key meeting with Bush and Stimson on Anglo-American nuclear cooperation.

23: London; drives to Chequers.

24-26: Chequers; returns London to meet Polish President Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz.

27: London; War Cabinet; House speech on Mussolini’s fall: “one of the principal criminals.”

28: London; audience with King George VI; speaks in Commons.

29: London; War Cabinet meeting; meets Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong.

30: London; War Cabinet; departs for Chequers.

31: Chequers; guests include King Peter of Yugoslavia.

August

1-2: London; War Cabinet on 2nd.

3: London; Royal audience; meets U.S. senators; speaks in the Commons; hosts dinner for Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands.

4: London; Commons speech, War Cabinet; chairs Pacific War Council meeting; meets with Orde Wingate; leaves before midnight via train for the Clyde.

5: Arrives Faslane, transfers to the Queen Mary.

6-8: At sea aboard the Queen Mary.

9: Arrives Halifax; entrains for 700-mile, 22-hour overnight trip to Quebec City.

10: Arrives Quebec; meets Mackenzie King; resides at the Citadel.

11: Quebec with Mackenzie King; Canadian War Cabinet; entrains for Hyde Park, New York.

12: Views Niagara Falls from Canadian side; arrives Hyde Park.

13-14: Hyde Park with Roosevelt; entrains for Quebec evening of 14th.

15: Arrives Quebec; meets with Mackenzie King and British Chiefs of Staff.

16: Quebec City.

17-24: “Quadrant”: 1943 Quebec Conference.

17: Wolfe’s Cove, Quebec: Meets FDR’s train and confers with FDR.

18: Quebec; meets with FDR and Mackenzie King; Stalin invited to meet them in Alaska.

19: Quebec; British and Combined Chiefs of Staff meetings; UK-US atomic agreement signed.

20: Quebec; drives to fish with FDR at Laurentide Park; returns to Quebec.

21-23: Quebec; meets with British and Combined Chiefs of Staff; FDR and Mackenzie King.

24: Quebec; meets press at Citadel; sees off FDR; joint communiqué on Conference.

25: Quebec City; drives to fish Lac des Neiges.

26: Lac des Neiges fishing camp; drives to mountain retreat at La Cabane.

27-30: La Cabane.

31: Returns to Quebec, broadcasts on Conference; entrains for Washington.

September

1: Arrives Washington; meets with President Roosevelt.

2: White House; meets with General Marshall.

3: White House; meets with Bernard Baruch.

4: White House; questioned by reporters at press luncheon.

5: British Embassy, Washington; with Dominion ministers, British members of Combined Chiefs and Supply Council; entrains for Boston in evening.

6: Boston and Cambridge; Harvard honorary degree and speech on Anglo-American unity.

7: Returns by train to Washington, resumes talks with FDR.

8-10: White House; continued talks with the President.

11: White House; meets U.S. Chiefs of Staff; entrains for Hyde Park.

12: Hyde Park with FDR; entrains for Halifax in evening; Allies invade Italy.

13-14: Via train through Maine and New Brunswick to Halifax; embarks on HMS Renown.

15-18: At sea aboard HMS Renown.

19: Renown docks in Greenock; shipboard church service; entrains for London.

20: London; War Cabinet.

21: London; Commons speech promises invasion of France when US-UK judge right.

22: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

23: London; Audience with King George VI.

24: London; memorial service for Sir Kingsley Wood; War Cabinet.

25-26: Chequers; meetings with Mountbatten on plans for Combined Operations.

27: Returns London; meets with officials.

28: London; Royal Audience; War Cabinet; Albert Hall speech to British women.

29: London; meets Ambassador to Spain Sir Samuel Hoare.

30: London: meets with Vincent Massey; meeting of Special Operations Executive (SOE).

October

1: London; luncheon with fellow officer from 1895 Cuban campaign, Reggie Barnes.

2-3: Chequers.

4: London; War Cabinet.

5: London; War Cabinet; meets with South African Prime Minister Jan Smuts.

6-7: London; daily War Cabinets; chairs daily Chiefs of Staff Committee.

8: London; visits critically ill Admiral Sir Dudley Pound; drives to Chequers.

9-10: Chequers; guests include Jan Smuts, Anthony Eden.

11: Returns London; War Cabinet.

12: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

13-14: London; House of Commons, War Cabinet, returns Chequers on 15th.

15-16: Chequers.

18: London; War Cabinet.

19: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet; House of Commons; Chiefs of Staff Committee.

20: London; Queen Wilhelmina luncheon; dines with King, Smuts, War Cabinet.

21: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

22: London; Visits daughter Mary at her Hyde Park AA Battery.

23-24: Chequers; guests include Noël Coward and Lord Beaverbrook.

25: London; War Cabinet.

26: London; Royal audience; Commons; funeral procession for Admiral Pound.

27: London; War Cabinet; House of Commons.

28: London; House of Commons.

29: London; Chairs Chiefs of Staff committee; departs for Chequers.

30-31: Chequers: Jan Smuts among guests.

November

1: London; War Cabinet.

2: London; Royal audience; War Cabinet.

3: London; dines with King George VI.

4: London; War Cabinet; speaks in the Commons.

5: London; visits Harrow with brother Jack and Leo Amery; drives to Chequers.

6-7: Chequers; guests include Randolph Churchill and Brendan Bracken.

8: Returns London; luncheon given by Smuts; War Cabinet.

9: London; Lord Mayor’s luncheon speech “The Task Ahead”; House of Commons.

10: London, War Cabinet; Commons; dinner by King and Queen for Regent of Iraq.

11: London; speaks in Commons.

12: Departs London by special train for Plymouth; boards HMS Renown.

13-15: At sea aboard HMS Renown, suffering from heavy cold.

16: Renown arrives at Algiers; sails for Malta in evening.

17: Renown arrives at Malta; goes ashore to overnight at San Anton Palace.

18: Malta; Chiefs of Staff meeting; heavy cold persists.

19: Malta; sails for Egypt aboard HMS Renown.

20: At sea aboard HMS Renown.

21: Renown arrives Alexandria; flies to Cairo to reside at Villa Bleu.

22-26: First Cairo Conference.

23: Cairo first session; drives with Roosevelt to Pyramids; meets with Marshall.

24: Cairo; meetings with FDR and military commanders.

25-26: Cairo; meets FDR and Chiang Kai‐shek. Thanksgiving dinner, FDR’s villa, 25th.

27: Flies to Teheran; drives to British Legation.

28 December 1: Teheran Conference.

28: Teheran; first plenary meeting; FDR hosts dinner in his quarters at the Russian Embassy.

29: Teheran; presents Stalingrad Sword of Honour to Stalin; dinner at Russian Embassy.

30: Teheran; WSC’s 69th birthday; audience with Shah of Iran; FDR hosts luncheon at the Russian embassy; dinner in honor of WSC at the British Legation.

December

1: Teheran with FDR and Stalin; final plenary session of the Conference.

2: Flies for Cairo; arrives mid-afternoon; meets with FDR.

3: Cairo with FDR; inspects his old regiment, the 4th Queen’s Own Hussars.

4-6: Second Cairo Conference with Combined Chiefs, FDR, Turkish President Inönü.

7: Cairo; farewells to FDR and Inönü; meets with Smuts; hosts Combined Chiefs dinner.

8: Cairo; audiences with King Farouk and King George of the Hellenes.

9: Cairo; farewell to Smuts.

10: Cairo; meets King Peter of Yugoslavia and Regent of Iraq Abd al-Ilah.

11: Flies to Tunis; tells Eisenhower, “I am completely at the end of my tether.”

12-13: Carthage; ill with pneumonia and atrial fibrillation; specialists summoned.

14: Carthage; medical condition worsens; Moran fears WSC may die.

15-17: Carthage, ill; Attlee announces WSC’s condition to Commons on 16th.

18-23: Carthage, ill; despite periodic alarms, makes slow progress.

24: Carthage; despite illness chairs military conference.

25: Carthage; confers with Eisenhower and Alexander; “magnificent Christmas dinner.”

26: Carthage; condition improves.

27: Flies to Marrakesh to complete recuperation.

28-30: Marrakesh; “I am now able to transact business fully”; mountain picnic, 30th.

31: Marrakesh; meets with Eisenhower and Montgomery; celebrates New Year.
